ai.summary: Exe Valley Way is a demanding long-distance hike that traces the valley of the River Exe across the UK. At 675.2 km, it is a strenuous route designed for experienced trekkers seeking a substantial wilderness challenge.
ai.terrain_summary: The route combines quiet country lanes, farm tracks, woodlands and some exposed hillside sections. Expect varied surfaces, frequent ascents and descents, river crossings, and potentially wet and muddy conditions. Navigation is straightforward in parts but can require map reading in more remote sections.
ai.safety_notes: This is a hard trek. Plan for multi-day walking, inform someone of your itinerary, and check the weather forecast. Carry navigation tools (map and compass, and optionally a GPS), a reliable light source, enough water and energy-rich food, and appropriate clothing for rain and cold. Some sections have limited mobile reception and remote terrain; consider hiking with a partner or arranging a support plan. Be mindful of livestock on farmland and respect local access rules. Ensure you have daylight to complete each day and carry a lightweight emergency shelter or space blanket.
recommended_gear: Sturdy waterproof hiking boots with ankle support
Weatherproof jacket and trousers (Gore-Tex or equivalent)
Breathable base layers and mid-layer for temperature changes
Map and compass (plus optional GPS device)
Water bottles or hydration bladder (2-3 L capacity)
First aid kit for long-distance hikes
Headlamp or torch with spare batteries
Emergency bivy sack or lightweight sleeping bag
Emergency beacon or phone with offline maps
ai.best_seasons: Late spring to early autumn (roughly March to October) offer the best conditions with longer daylight and milder weather. Winter sections are more challenging and require advanced skills and equipment.
